title: Historical Stock Splits and Corporate Actions of Independent Bank Corp (Michigan) Stock

content.text: Independent Bank Corp (Michigan) is incorporated and goes public through an initial public offering (IPO). The company starts trading on the stock market.
Independent Bank Corp (Michigan) announces a 2-for-1 stock split. Shareholders receive an additional share for each share held, effectively doubling the number of shares outstanding.
Independent Bank Corp (Michigan) acquires Michigan Heritage Bancorp, expanding its presence and customer base in Michigan's banking industry.
A 3-for-2 stock split is declared by Independent Bank Corp (Michigan). Shareholders receive 1.5 additional shares for every 2 shares held.

As the financial crisis unfolds, Independent Bank Corp (Michigan) faces substantial challenges. In 2008, the company participates in the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) and receives a $72 million investment from the U.S. Treasury.

To enhance the stock's marketability and regain compliance with stock exchange listing requirements, Independent Bank Corp (Michigan) executes a 1-for-5 reverse stock split. Shareholders receive 1 share for every 5 shares held, reducing the number of shares outstanding.
Independent Bank Corp (Michigan) acquires TCSB Bancorp, further expanding its presence in Michigan and reinforcing its position as a leading community bank.

Independent Bank Corp (Michigan) declares a 10% stock dividend. Shareholders receive additional shares equivalent to 10% of their existing holdings as a dividend, increasing the number of shares they own.
